{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":2964211,"name":"Sam","username":"Sam7034","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/s/3ec8ea/{size}.png","created_at":"2021-08-05T18:42:32.167Z","cooked":"

Our team has been building a swerve drive. When programming it using Java we come to an error. At 0/360 degrees, the module tends to spin out.

Our issue is the same as Swerve Modules flip 180 degrees periodically/conditionally
However the solution won’t work for our drive as we are using REV motors instead of falcon.

I believe the issue is with REV’s setRefrence() method of setting the swerve’s wheel position. The solution in the attached post doesn’t help us as it doesn’t change the fact the the setRefrence() method only takes a desired position and a control type as inputs. If the motor was set at 340 degrees and was told to set to 0, the method would -340 degrees instead of +20.

Any help would be appreciated

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":5,"updated_at":"2021-08-05T18:42:32.167Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":177,"reads":189,"readers_count":188,"score":922.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":395394,"topic_slug":"swerve-drive-spinning-out-and-flipping-at-0-degrees-using-rev","display_username":"Sam","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/swerve-modules-flip-180-degrees-periodically-conditionally/393059","internal":true,"reflection":false,"title":"Swerve Modules flip 180 degrees periodically/conditionally","clicks":29}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":49284,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Software Lead"},"post_url":"/t/swerve-drive-spinning-out-and-flipping-at-0-degrees-using-rev/395394/1","custom_user_title":"Software Lead","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":2964220,"name":"Tyler Veness","username":"calcmogul","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/calcmogul/{size}/128045_2.png","created_at":"2021-08-05T19:20:58.070Z","cooked":"

As you can see from that thread, you need to be able to wrap the encoder input (have the end of the left side of the range be treated as the same point as the right side of the range). I can’t find that feature in the Spark Max’s PID controller API, so your choices are:

  1. Use WPILib’s PIDController or ProfiledPIDController instead. Call enableContinuousInput() to enable it. That thread mentioned some bugs in continuous input mode that have since been fixed upstream, so you’d need to copy the latest MathUtil and PIDController classes into your robot code.
  2. Implement the logic from WPILib yourself so you can pass a corrected reference to setReference().
github.com

wpilibsuite/allwpilib/blob/main/wpimath/src/main/java/edu/wpi/first/math/MathUtil.java#L44-L56

    

  1. public static double inputModulus(double input, double minimumInput, double maximumInput) {
    2. 

  2.   double modulus = maximumInput - minimumInput;
    3. 

  3. 

  4.   // Wrap input if it's above the maximum input
    5. 

  5.   int numMax = (int) ((input - minimumInput) / modulus);
    6. 

  6.   input -= numMax * modulus;
    7. 

  7. 

  8.   // Wrap input if it's below the minimum input
    9. 

  9.   int numMin = (int) ((input - maximumInput) / modulus);
    10. 

  10.   input -= numMin * modulus;
    11. 

  11. 

  12.   return input;
    13. 

  13. }
    14.
github.com

wpilibsuite/allwpilib/blob/main/wpimath/src/main/java/edu/wpi/first/math/controller/ProfiledPIDController.java#L277-L315

    

  1. /**
    2. 

  2.  * Returns the next output of the PID controller.
    3. 

  3.  *
    4. 

  4.  * @param measurement The current measurement of the process variable.
    5. 

  5.  * @return The controller's next output.
    6. 

  6.  */
    7. 

  7. public double calculate(double measurement) {
    8. 

  8.   if (m_controller.isContinuousInputEnabled()) {
    9. 

  9.     // Get error which is smallest distance between goal and measurement
    10. 

  10.     double errorBound = (m_maximumInput - m_minimumInput) / 2.0;
    11. 

  11.     double goalMinDistance =
    12. 

  12.         MathUtil.inputModulus(m_goal.position - measurement, -errorBound, errorBound);
    13. 

  13.     double setpointMinDistance =
    14. 

  14.         MathUtil.inputModulus(m_setpoint.position - measurement, -errorBound, errorBound);
    15. 

  15. 

  16.     // Recompute the profile goal with the smallest error, thus giving the shortest path. The goal
    17. 

  17.     // may be outside the input range after this operation, but that's OK because the controller
    18. 

  18.     // will still go there and report an error of zero. In other words, the setpoint only needs to
    19. 

  19.     // be offset from the measurement by the input range modulus; they don't need to be equal.
    20. 

  20.     m_goal.position = goalMinDistance + measurement;
    21.

FWIW, this issue seems to come up often any time there is a new motor controller; there’s the thread mentioned in the lead post (reported on Falcon 500), and years ago the same issue existed on the original CAN-based motor controller, the Jaguar: Jaguar Speed & Position Control with Encoders - #17 by nuttle.
